Error 1: People love taking shortcuts when making decisions ‚Äî smart people more so than others because they believe they are better than others based on their prior accomplishments. #MultiFactorAnalysis #StartupTips #decisionmaking

Error 2: People place more emphasis on recent events than the event warrants, such as pouring money into bitcoin after bitcoin price sruge.
#MultiFactorAnalysis #StartupTips #decisionmaking

Error 3: We also anchor our valuations to recent events. For example, If an IPO is successful, funding to startups goes up. 
 #MultiFactorAnalysis #StartupTips #decisionmaking

Error No. 4: We value the popular view especially shared among more successful people. Case in point is YC demo days.
#MultiFactorAnalysis #StartupTips #decisionmaking

Error No. 5: We think that what we have available is all that‚Äôs available.
#MultiFactorAnalysis #StartupTips #decisionmaking

ŸçError 6: And finally, when we succeed we take a lot more credit for it than the responsibility we take when we fail. 
#MultiFactorAnalysis #StartupTips #decisionmaking

@arms_tips This prevents actress aura from being something you can spam as freely and quickly as, say, Springman/Springtron/Max Brass‚Äôs deflect, and heavily encourages its use while staying at a distance, deeply affecting which play styles are viable for Twintelle.

@arms_tips Helix‚Äôs tower mode is similar in that part of the counter to it is that you similarly have to commit to using it for an extended duration to get the most out of it and it is much more risky to use in close quarters.
@arms_tips I would also put Ribbon Girl‚Äôs multiple jumps in this category, since her fast fall mixup combined with 5 jumps reduces the risk factor immensely if she keeps her distance.

@arms_tips Generally, the abilities that have much larger drawback windows (full charge req) provide permanent or semi-permanent boosts that allow continued movement, like dragon arm, EMP, Brass‚Äôs super armor, and Misango‚Äôs masks. And in the first three cases, the characters have >1 ability

@arms_tips I definitely think a few characters could use buffs because of their abilities being deficient in this pattern (Misango as noted above, Byte & Barq in general just needs something worthwhile), but Twintelle isn‚Äôt even in the top 3 characters in the meta.

@arms_tips That said, for the sake of making the play style more interesting, I‚Äôd be all for taking some kind of nerf to actress aura in exchange for a more engaging active component. Same goes for characters like Mechanica and Master Mummy tbh.

@arms_tips Coyle is at the top of the meta right now, but I‚Äôm not so sure I would point to her ability so much as a combination of her recovery frames and dash distance that need tweaking. Though, like you said, it‚Äôs ultimately the combination of multiple factors that prove problematic.
@arms_tips I think this is part of why I‚Äôm more in the ‚Äònerf Coyle‚Äôs overall mobility‚Äô camp than ‚Äònerf her third arm state‚Äô
@arms_tips OTOH, it does work for him and thematically it would make sense for the game‚Äôs two ‚Äòfinal bosses‚Äô to have that commonality, so maybe I really am on board with the Coyle idea üòÜ
Changing behavior and getting it to stick is not easy when introducing a new concept or workflow so making that awesome out of the gate helps a ton. Other SaaS companies should take note üòé

With millions of visitors a day, the Archive is one of the most popular websites on the internet - easily in the top 250, occasionally dipping into the top 200. Right now we're #167 worldwide, according to Alexa. alexa.com/siteinfo/archi‚Ä¶

In general, half our traffic is The Wayback Machine, also known as The Thing That Shows You The Old Web, or Online History's Killer App, or Jesus Christ They Have My Geocities Page. It goes by many names. Half of everything hits that sub-site. Everything else is the other half. https://t.co/Gq9WbcQOuT

Why is the Wayback slow? Well, it's a combination of multiple factors. The saved websites have to be tracked down to the server set that has them, and then the webpage has to be unpacked for you from compressed datasets, and then rendered. It just takes a while. https://t.co/hVOfAux5yU

My boss loves keeping track of what's in there. The Wayback has over 750 billion URLs and related content saved in its stacks, all of them instantly requestable. Instantly requestable does not mean instantly loaded, though.
twitter.com/brewster_kahle‚Ä¶

I watch the Slack channel where Kenji and David and Steve and Mark and Bill and Owen and Corentin and Vangelis and others are all sweating daily to keep the whole endeavor afloat and growing by terabytes and handling hundreds of bugfixes and I can personally guarantee no sleeping https://t.co/DnerQCHlsB

Search is in constant flux for the last year. Thanks for all your hard work, Aaron! Keeping the lights on the extensive search of dozens of petabytes of content going, as well as full-text search, AS WELL as optimizing, adding facet searches, and so on, means it's sometimes slow.
Another possibility is someone is finding Everything Else slow. Everything Else would be specific items, or specific collections, or doing a search. Let's break those down.

We'll never be as fast as the goog or the bing or the duck but we're also able to do a whole range of searches and deep-scanning that others do not do at the moment, and we're doing it for millions of searches a month, so that's a lot of what's going on. Aaron's on this ALWAYS. https://t.co/xzUJIXpgL6

And perhaps, maybe? You're getting some sort of slow download. Like you're downloading a CD image or a 10gb item or a bunch of mp3s and something seems a little slower than you expect. Well, part of that is we don't do tiered memberships - everyone gets the max we can handle.

Occasionally, a blog entry or a huge popular item will mean a set of machines get HAMMERED. We have some "priority" machines we can move a popular item to, and we do a lot of that shuffling, but until it kicks off, the machines might run slow handling the onslaught.

Onslaughts are great, they're what we're here for, and we don't tack on ads or tracking cookies or sell your info or even really keep it while you're doing it. So we don't pay top dollar for maximum everything because there's no shady undercarriage carrying that "awesome" speed.

If there's another reason we're slow or an experience you're finding where things are off, let us know. Let me know. We've found quietly dying disks, a router that's gone flako, an overheated machine, an unexpectedly popular item, and so on, and then we can move in and fix.

The situation we have is that since we DON'T talk to government agencies, ad networks, and privacy-destroying startups as our main (actual) users like a lot of those "fast" sites, we're gonna need to hear from our real users, you. Send along a tip or a note and we'll get on it.
Anyway, that's why we're slow. https://t.co/ACaBfXb2C0

1) have an activity that signals the start of your work day and the end of your work day. 

You work remote/at home/sometimes commute-less. You need something that signals your brain that test is over, play is paused, and work is commencing. Showers, walks, breakfast, whatever.

3) dedicate a space away from bed or the sofa for work. 

Protect your home spaces for rest and recovery!!!! Rolling over and taking meetings from bed will inevitably lead to the bed being the new desk, which means you sleep/rest less which j#is just as harmful, if not more...
...or desk to desk. Mimic that at home/coffee shop/wherever.

2) you need frequent small breaks to stave off sedentary life at the desk. 

Pomodoro or some other system. Get up and move for 5 minutes every hour. Between meetings. Whatever. 

You never realize how much movement you get in a ‚Äúdesk job‚Äù when you‚Äôre waking from mtg to mtg

You need to signal a start to your day and, more importantly, an end to your day. 

Working remote doesn‚Äôt mean you don‚Äôt have boundaries. And working remote means you have to be diligent about setting them, because there‚Äôs no bus to catch to signal it‚Äôs time to sign off
Than staying stationary at a desk. You need your home to stay a sanctuary for rest, recovery, and recreation.

4) TAKE SICK DAYS. Don‚Äôt prolong your sickness and recovery by ‚Äúfeeling well enough to take a call‚Äù.

Working from home doesn‚Äôt mean that sickness, injury and other things that would keep you from an office goes away. 

They are just as important in working remote/from home.

5) connect with other humans. Don‚Äôt develop cabin fever or get stuck in isolation. Make friendship/family dates (I admittedly suck at this - my doctor prescribed me a weekly outdoor meetup w/strangers for this + depression battling).

6) create non-project connection points with your remote peers. You don‚Äôt have to be bffs over slack, but build culture and comaraderie, even if strictly professional, by engaging in virtual water cooler/non-stressful shop talk.

7) block out the same non-office distractions you would in a physical office. 

If twitters distracting for you, limit it during the day. Work away from Netflix or whatever you have poppin in your living room. Treat your ‚Äúon‚Äù hours as you would in a physical office.

8) STOCK YOUR SNACK/COFFEE/TEA BAR!!! Nuff said. 

As an aside, DO NOT GET ALL YOUR LUNCHES VIA DELIVERY APPS. 

Either cook them, microwave them, or go get them. Again, time away from the screen + social interaction. Break up the sedentary potential. And save yourself some $$

LASTLY, TAKE TIME OFF!!!!!!!! 
Working remote/from home doesn‚Äôt mean you don‚Äôt ‚Äúwork hard‚Äù or that you don‚Äôt deserve downtime. 

And if you have unlimited PTO, I suggest you endeavor to take 3-4 weeks off per year. 

What works for me? I take 3-5 days per quarter. YMMV.

Your team needs a refreshed, invigorated and engaged teammate/mentor/manager/colleague. 

No one wins when you‚Äôre frayed, burned out and at exhaustion. I‚Äôve learned the hard way multiple times.
Once everything was installed, I was able to build an app in no time. Not too shabby!

The key to building an audience, if you're just starting out, is to *narrow your focus.*

The twittersphere is full of discussions across an infinite # of topics. But the trick is to pick ONE (maybe 2) things to talk about consistently for awhile.

No one is entitled to an audience.

It's earned when people can associate you w/ a particular expertise or trait (insightful takes on X, Y type of content) that delivers consistent VALUE.

Earn your followers' attention, THEN you can branch out more broadly (or start shitposting)

You won't stand out if you're covering too broad of an area.

Pick a topic. For say, a few weeks/months, share your expertise, learn out loud, and engage w/ others. 

You can always experiment with your focus later, but you need time to let yourself learn / let things play out.

A little over a year ago, I had ~1000 followers. I decided to narrow my focus and consistently talk about my 2 areas of expertise: Startup Hiring & Diversity.

Nearly 10K now, and it's been such a fun year! 

I have more tips to share later, but in the meantime, consider *focus.*

If your ideas about coalition building start with *bullying* and *shaming* people you want help from... umm... I have bad news for you.

We don't have to be besties and bake each other cupcakes. We don't even have to like each other, but we have to have respect and trust.
It may be hard for me to explain the nuance in a tweet, but there's even a major difference between calling someone out for their actions, and making judgements about who they are as people.

In the first case, you leave space for redemption and change. 

Note that there's still *totally* a thing where people aren't ready or able to reckon with their failings, and they feel like you are bullying them, even when the message is delivered with compassion and empathy.

In the second case (making judgements), *your* actions suggest that you have already decided that they are irredeemable or incapable of change... 

In which case, what would inspire them to engage or work with you at all?

Here's another thread where I brought up some thoughts about making judgements:

The 2008 global financial collapse was again terrible. This was so bad that I was missing 2001. I managed to survive 2008 as well. (3/14)

I survived 2 downturns earlier - first in 2000/2001 dot.com bust followed by 9/11. The next few years were bad for #ecommerce. That's when we launched Fabmall supermarkets in 2002, later acquired by @AdityaBirlaGrp (#More supermarket), now acq. by @amazonIN (2/14)
But things are different this time. In addition to all the above attributes, people are dying. Millions will die because of the #CoronavirusCrisis Millions more will die of hunger. (5/14)

Common attributes in both downturns - job losses, shutdowns, massive drop in valuations, no funds, no capital, big drop in revenues, unable to see beyond a quarter. Surviving every month was the agenda.(4/14)

Lesson 2: Downturns are good. #startups especially funded ones sometimes get into bad habits in good times - excessive marketing spends, trophy hiring, impractical expansions. Now's the time to get rid of these habits and make things sustainable. (8/14)
Lesson 1: This too shall pass. Good times fly fast. Fortunately, bad times also end, even if they crawl. Chin up - good times will come AGAIN. (7/14)

We are in un-chartered territory. No one knows what will happen. #Entrepreneurs and #startups must read all survival tips with this rider - no one really knows. With this assumption, here are a few tips. Take what makes sense. (6/14)

Lesson 4: Forget margins. Focus on cash flows. In 2008, we enjoyed 40% margins and 30 days credit with book publishers. In 2009, I personally met every publisher and changed this to 20% and 90 days. It made a huge difference to us.  (10/14)
Lesson 3: Change org structure. In good times, around 60% of headcount is focused on directly / indirectly impacting revenues. Push this up to 85% or more now. (9/14)
Downturns build steel. #startups who come through can face future challenges with greater confidence. Of course, you also need some good fortune while you try to hang on. (13/14)

While you do all this, review your runway. Any funding in the next 6-9 months will be tough. Do whatever it takes to make your funds last 1+ year. Simple rule: re-negotiate every single existing contract. There are no holy cows.  (12/14)
Lesson 5: Communicate. Talk to employees. If as a #Founder you are not sure what's going to happen, spare a thought about your employees. If in doubt, over-communicate. (11/14)
Don't forget. This too shall pass. God bless. (14/14)
These steps might vary depending on your type of music business, so it‚Äôs more of a guideline :)

A startup is not just about starting a business. It is about solving a problem that affects many people (‚Äúpain points‚Äù), which doesn‚Äôt seem to have a solution yet.

It is about innovating the way we do things. Doing things differently.

That‚Äôs why startup is always abt tech.

You get emotionally attached to the idea and you think your idea/solution is the best there is in the market.

You pour your heart and soul into it. Spend many late nights doing prototypes to see whether it works.

All startup founders thought their idea can change the world.

Stories abt startup founders are almost similar around the world.

You experienced a snag. You felt things should have been better.

You get curious & feel you have a solution to the problem.

You explored the idea and thought this could work.

Unfortunately not everyone will be the next Mark Zuckerberg or Larry Page or Sergei Brin or Elon Musk or Jeff Bezos.

If all startup ideas are great ideas (and most of them are great), why is it that most startups failed and not even 1% ever made it big?

I learnt the answer to this the hard way.

When we went to the market 18 months ago, we thought all was sorted out.

Our price was super competitive, we have data science niche that competitors don‚Äôt have.

I run financial modelling and realised I was sitting on multi-mln idea

But the first year was a big struggle.

Every week you encountered problems. If it‚Äôs not product related, it‚Äôs talent related. 

So many interest yet the take up rate was so low. 

Every 3-4 months we had to raise a new capital.

We could have sunk in the first year. 

Eventually I had to raise additional RM8 million from seed investors (local & overseas) to steady the ship.

Lots of product iteration - what was a good idea then had to be tweaked, not because the idea is bad, but the market takes longer

You literally had to roll up your sleeve and fix as much as you can.

Often it starts with working your team leaders and curating your team to have the right mindset & hunger for making a difference.

We are hitting 20th month in the market and I think we will be OK, even after COVID.

Revenue growth is good; the iterated products gain traction in the market, the brand is recognised decently.

We may just survive birth pangs of a startup.

I wish I didn‚Äôt have to go through the painful one year to establish a viable & sustainable business.

I really thought that it was easier and there were times I felt it was unfair.

But that painful one year starting my startup taught me many wonderful lessons.

FIRST:

Idea alone is not enough.

Even the greatest idea is not guaranteed a runaway commercial success.

Converting an idea into a practical business project is like moving a mountain.

The greater the idea, the bigger is the mountain.

SECOND:

Great idea becomes a great business when you stay long enough on the problem.

It takes patience and loyalty to stay long enough iterating the products & understanding the market.

Even if the market is slow to catch up, the market is always right.

THIRD:

A startup can only survive if you are damn stingy. Financial prudence is super important.

It‚Äôs always about cash runaway.

It is also abt the skills to bring in a variety of revenue streams while waiting your main products turn around.

FOURTH:

A startup is about a group of talents who believe in making a difference.

It is about misfits; a heterogeneous group of people with diverse talents, behaviour, style who are bonded together by one mission: the belief that they can make a differenfe and the loyalty to it

I don‚Äôt know yet whether I will ever make the multi-million return that my projection showed when I started 2 years ago.

On paper, the valuation is RM50m (after 2 years) & we transacted at RM50m with seed investors.

And I feel it‚Äôs not bad for 18-month work.

We are expanding headcount by 20% (when other businesses are retrenching), we are moving to a new office.

There‚Äôs a sense of optimism after the hell of the first year in business.

But I also know not to be misled by the sense of optimism.

Because life is actually quite fair to each of us.

If it is so easy to become a startup multi-millionaire, then it‚Äôs not fair to those who slog it out and worked for years to build their business.

The bigger the dream, the harder it is. And more pains waiting.

But everyone should have (at least) a small ambition to start a startup with one idea.

You may start small and work after office (of your day job) to develop the prototype.

So long you remember one great tip:

Stay longer on the problem, there is no shortcut to success.

I may just waste 20-min creating a thread (I just learnt how to create a thread yesterday ha3) that nobody else reads, but I hope to those who dream for a bigger thing in life - my sharing could have been of some help.

building a successful startup is the process of **transferring your enthusiasm and vision to thousands of people as quickly as possible.** 

(let "quickly" be 3-10 years)

you must operate under the assumption that you are a prophet. someday soon people will say "AhHh so smart!"

but i understand the maker mindset. 

in fact i'm actually  a musician, not a "programmer" or "marketer" or "founder" or "manager" or whatever.

and Ira Glass nails it here. best 115 second investment of your day: youtu.be/PbC4gqZGPSY

the irony of building a great company, aka a money printing machine:

1. you will do the MOST work in the beginning when you are improvising, talent-less and underpaid

2. you will do the LEAST work near the end when you are 10x wiser and rich

fair? idk. i don't make the rules.

so you need to stay motivated along the way.

Radical transparency is in demand, and since it's still relatively rare, it makes companies stand out. It can also work as social proof, while increasing trust and customer loyalty.
For example, potential customers may be hesitant to sign up if your revenue is low, and copycats may show up if your revenue is high. But many founders swear by it, especially in the beginning.
There are even people out there who prefer working with open startups to the degree that they specifically seek them out. Of course, there is some risk involved.

Then tell your story as it unfolds (including the numbers) on social media.

For more growth bites üëâ indiehackers.com/growth-bites

Create a dedicated /open page sharing your revenue, users, traffic, and so on in numbers and charts. Add yourself to open startup lists. And if you haven't already done so, put your product on the IH product page.

Take @mattiasgeniar, who opened up @OhDearApp
 ($8,000/mo). He attributes up to 3% of his current signups to this transparency.

Do not think that you will be spared when you infringe the IP rights of another just because you are a tech founder. 

So ask yourself if you have the right to post that last photo you posted on IG describing the million-dollar invention your company is sitting on.

It is understandable that you are very excited to pitch before that BIG investor, however, you need to know that investors will conduct their due diligence. 

They'd want to know if you, as a founder, are conscious of your IP and have taken steps to protect it.

So, where you are pitching about an amazing invention, it wouldn't be strange to hear an investor ask if the invention is patented; if the patent application is in the works or if it is the case that you can't be bothered about all those legal stuff. https://t.co/jRnLGHveat

Where this is the case, you should consider filing an application for patent (over your invention) before making disclosure in a pitch/presentation.

Please find out what is obtainable in your country.

Many countries have a very strict patent system which requires that an invention be strictly novel before a patent can be granted over it.

This may mean that where you disclose the invention in a pitch, prior to filling for a patent, you may lose the right to protect it.
By now, you should know that paying your co-founder, employees or independent contractors for the work done does not grant you automatic ownership of the intellectual property in their work.

Sometimes, it might be better to protect your invention by measures other than a patent, such as a trade secret.

The best way to protect your IP in this regard, during pitches, is to have the investor sign a non-disclosure agreement (NDA). https://t.co/vN9flFlBrr

Documentation is KEY!

Do not do business or disclose your IP to another on the basis of trust.

Emails are excellent in keeping communication trails. Use them!

If you've made disclosures via a call, send a follow-up email detailing all you've discussed.üòÅ

However, you shouldn't expect an investor to sign an NDA just because you have shoved it in his/her face.

An NDA is a practical alternative where your business is largely "up and running" and you have made efforts to seek the protection of the law, where necessary.

You should also never make the mistake of undervaluing your IP. That you are just starting out does not mean the law cannot protect you. Just as it doesn't mean that your IP is free for the taking by large organizations.

The law is your friend.üòÅ

It is also not cool to say that you can't or haven't protected your IP rights because it is expensive to do so or because lawyers are expensive.

There's a lawyer for every pocket and many lawyers are willing to work in exchange for equity. (A Pretty good deal if you ask us.) https://t.co/iad5CwEHMO

Finally, there's the question of whether you can use random but beautiful photos found online in your pitch deck without an attending copyright issue.

The simple answer is you should not.ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è (except of course they are stock photos made freely available)

This is a very long one but you should take it seriously.

Respectfully,
TheIPstream

Many investors may know that you've used infringing materials in your deck and may not care. However, you don't want to risk an investor holding an opinion that you don't think much about infringing the IP rights of others.

1. Your profile is a landing page. Optimize copy, images, the pinned answer for the action you want your readers to take.

2. Don't spam. It'll just result in your account getting downgraded/blocked.

3. Format your content so it‚Äôs easy to read. This helps rankings.

4. Update answers that are important for you from time to time. Quora's algorithm will reward you!

5. Link to reputable resources (not ONLY your website) in your answers.

6. Don't put a link to your website in every answer. Quora will consider this as spam.

7. For every ‚Äúmarketing question‚Äù answer at least 3 general questions, like ‚ÄúWhen did you realize that you‚Äôre old?‚Äù or ‚ÄúWhat irritates you?‚Äù

8. Put the name of the company in the first paragraph of the answer to get attention from users that just skim through them.

9. Use custom credentials for different answers. We got a lot of direct and branded search traffic from this.

10. If you have well-known competitors, answer the questions, where users look for their reviews or alternatives. Those are highly convertible topics for us.

11. Don‚Äôt trash your competitors. The community would not appreciate this.

In one of the answers, I said that I think that TopTal is a great company to hire developers from and we look up to them. We got a lot of clients from that answer and they were thanking me for being fair.

12. Answer questions that rank in Google. For example, if you search ‚ÄòUpwork alternative‚Äô, one of Quora‚Äôs questions is in the top-5 results. 

13. Buying upvotes is a short-term game. You can do it, but in the long run, in some time you‚Äôll lose your positions.

14. Ask friends, who are active on Quora, to upvote you and initiate conversations. Join communities where Quora users support each other. 

Not the most white-hat methods, but I don‚Äôt think we would be able to get as many leads if there was no boost from the friends/community.

15. Answer Wiki is the first thing that users see, make sure you add your information there but don‚Äôt be spammy. Quora answer Wiki can only reflect the information from the existing answers, so answer the question first.

16. If you see that some answers are performing well, try boosting them through the Quora ad network. They have great targeting tools. The only thing we were not able to figure out was their conversion tracking, so it‚Äôs a spray and pray game for us. But I‚Äôll keep investing there.

I hope this is helpful.

With new technology or a growing market you'd be lucky if people notice your entire idea/space at all. And multiple players show market activity. This also fuels VC interest and might funnel big capital into market creation you didn't have to pay for.

You can differentiate with being more open, or different focus, or don't use subscription, or sometimes you simply have to be in the list of 'alternatives to' and finally you can compete on price, although that's usually a very bad idea.
I would say the only actually dangerous thing to your existence is for giant companies to simply add what you do to their product, or give it away for free. Your competition is not other startups.

Gav explained the key features of a metaprotocol: generality and scalability, as well as explaining the val. of abstraction, generality and flexibility at the level of protocols of protocols. 

He clearly explained their purpose in the context of parachains too. (Layer0-1).

One very poignant point Gav made on parachains: 
 
Parachains are not just a smart contract, but an entire #Blockchain. Implementing a SC is easy, but you can't implement a blockchain inside a smart contract.. This really illustrates the value of parachains in the #DOT eco.

Gav also clearly explained the clear differences between parachains and parathreads, discussing different use case examples for the two distinct designs/purposes. He also made the point that Polkadot is focused on symbiotic, composite solutions (hence the multichain vision)

Laure raised the issue of retirement of parachains and the subscription/renewal model. Gav really smashed any seed of doubt here, explained grace periods and the slowing down effects but not cancellation of non-renewers.

Laura then asked about @Polkadot's IPO, or Parachain lease agreements (PLOs), referencing ICOs (so infamously brought to the fore in Ethereum '17). Again, Gav made it clear they are fund sourcing mechanisms..  Of course, some building on Ethereum are launching ICO2.0 style too

Perhaps in a very odd and certainly impartial move, Laura said "There are people from the SEC who listen to my show".. I instantly wondered... ummm, would she have the same tone with someone like Vitalik, who she has pinned to where twitter feed? Not sure guys, not sure..

What was very interesting: Laura often uses an interesting question & subjective statement technique. For example, she stated 'Parity has a history of security lapses"- negative oriented question by design. Gav smashed it with a clear answer about security work on $DOT.

Some other key highlights in the discussion were Gav's points on Bridges, compatibility, optionality, meta-ecosystem design and he also addressed Laura's composability question head on and with ease, explain the different objectives & capacities of Ethereum & Polkadot.

Perhaps the most salient point Gav repeated was that from the outset, he never set out to build a single blockchain (hence the meta-protocol and parachain & substrate architecture). His focus is on cooperation, collaboration, bringing, free-trade among top platforms, coopetition

A further display of journalistic temerity came when Laura quickly retorted "no no, i did the math on it". This was based on here statement that Web2/Parity own 33% of DOTS combined. Gav had to explain that 'math' is inaccurate. The 1000 validator prog. for $KSM was mentioned.

When the topic of Ethereum came up, Gav was quick to point out that Ethereum is currently at it's beacon chain stage, not yet with sharding, or state transitions.. inferring a long roadmap ahead for Eth. Gav did say he hopes Polkadot can interface more and more with Ethereum..

Finally, Laura questioned Gav about $DOT possibly being a security (which is interesting considering the CFTC & SEC's stance on Eth. Gav: "DOTs are absolutely a utility, not a security". Enterprise chains discussed. Overall, Laura was professional (tones of bias). Gav smashed it!

The Intention of a follow-up email to a warm intro is to evoke Curiosity + Interest. It is like the first date after a friend introduced you to someone they thought you should meet. The goal, to get a second date. In this case, a follow-up email showing interest for a call/meet.

You are the expert in what you do. You are allowed a max of 3 jargons - and don't use it unless you absolutely have to. I am tired of hearing things such as ML-based, Artificial, GPT3 powered blah blah.

Keep things simple. Don't get into way too many details in the follow-up email (without even knowing if they are listening and are interested). Too much info before building trust is a way for the next side to say no.

The best-performing follow-up emails take less than 2-3 minutes to read. That's roughly 4-5, very simple sentences. 

Don't use one long complex sentence to hack this rule.

There is a good chance that the person making the intro is doing so because they are convinced you'll add value. If you have social proof, say it. "We helped companies x,y,z solve this problem, with x% success rate, which helped them achieve Y" is powerful.

Be very clear in your positioning as to what you can do. That helps if you can personalize it - based on whom you are connecting to. Talking to a VC, ask for an amount that fits their ticket size (if you are fundraising). Don't say, "Looking to raise 50K - 500K" ü§£
Make the next step obvious. If your pitch is strong enough, confidently propose an action - "Let me know when we can walk you through a demo", rather than "let me know".

Do some work on the person you are connecting to. Make a pitch that resonates with them. "We have seen companies like yours have a high cart abandonment rate and we can help improve that - significantly" - Identify what they know, care, and is in the background. bring to f/g.

A warm intro cuts through several layers :

Unaware - aware
Social proof
Proposing why they should be interested.

But it comes at the cost of social equity for the one introducing. If it works well, they get some extra points, else they lose some. Make it worth it.

Once the other side does respond favorably (or doesn't find the pitch enticing and says no), please do drop the introducer into bcc, so that you aren't flooding their inbox. It's no fun being the third wheel. :)

One of my friends is an electrician, and his work dried up when the economy tanked in 2009. 

He had a wife, two kids and another baby on the way, and had to hand his van back.

He would have known this was the beginning of the end for him.

I wanted to learn how to build websites and asked if he‚Äôd be my guinea pig. 

He bit my hand off down to my ankle.

We built a simple site and got him ranked top for ‚Äúkildare electrician‚Äù (Kildare being the county we live in here in Ireland).

Nothing happened.

Then one day a ‚Ç¨50 Google Ads voucher fell out of a book.  I setup an account, and got a few ads running.

Within a few days he rang saying ‚ÄúAndy, I‚Äôve had a call!‚Äù 

I remember standing up and wandering around in a daze thinking ‚ÄúWow, this actually works.‚Äù

We were really excited, and sat in his kitchen working out a bigger list of things to bid on.

We had new keywords such as ‚Äúdublin electrician‚Äù, ‚Äúwiring and rewiring‚Äù, and ‚Äúfuse board replacement‚Äù.

He was really excited about ‚Äúsmoke detector installation‚Äù because of all the landlords in Dublin that would need smoke detectors installed in their properties.

We setup a ‚ÄúServices‚Äù page on his site and listed each of the services as bullet points. We bid on each keyword and sent visitors to it.

He started getting calls and I remember him getting home late one Friday evening because he‚Äôd been fixing a washing machine in a town nearby.

He asked me to add ‚Äúwashing machine repairs‚Äù to the services page, saying that a lot of the people looked for an electrician because they wanted appliances repaired. 

We added that to his ‚ÄúServices‚Äù page, and created ads too.

After a month of the campaign running, we looked at his stats and found his ads had shown 10,000 times.

He‚Äôd had 300 clicks, and spent ‚Ç¨75.

He was more than happy spending the ‚Ç¨75 because he‚Äôd had enough work to cover the costs and put food on the table.
Most people would use Google Analytics to find out what those 300 visitors did when they landed on the page, but I was more interested in the 9,700 people who had seen our ad and sailed past.
When I analysed the 10,000 times his ad had shown, I found 2,000 were to do with people searching for electricians, especially in Dublin (the biggest city in Ireland).
We didn‚Äôt get many visitors though from these ‚Äúelectrician‚Äù searches, because every other electrician was also bidding on them and we were in a really low ad position.

We had hardly any clicks for wiring and rewiring, and no calls at all. 

I guessed our site wasn‚Äôt professional enough for people who were about to spend quite a bit of money and probably price shopping.

What I did find though, was half of all his impressions (that‚Äôs 5,000 impressions!) were down to either washing machine repairs, cooker repairs, or oven repairs.

He said he was absolutely swamped with all these appliance repairs calls.
Our ads had shown only 12 times for ‚Äúsmoke detector installation‚Äù, so I told him that wasn‚Äôt going to work.
People looking to repair their washing machine or cooker are also pretty desperate, and less likely to be price shopping because it‚Äôs a cheap enough job anyway.
Not only were there loads of people searching for appliance repairs, but there was much less competition in Google Ads, so we were in a really high ad position and getting lots of clicks.

So we threw away the electrical site we were building, and built a dublinwashingmachinerepairs site, a dublincookerrepairs site and a dublinovenrepairs site.

And then built a kildarewashingmachinerepairs site, a kildarecookerrepairs site, and a kildareovenrepairs site.
We turned off all the other ads, and just sent visitors to the correct website depending on what people were searching for.

His click-through-rate went from 4% to 8% overnight because someone searching for ‚Äúdublin washing machine repairs‚Äù saw an ad from Dublin washing machine repairs site instead of Dublin electrical site.

When they landed on the site and it said ‚ÄúDublin Washing Machine Repairs‚Äù, they didn‚Äôt wonder whether he fixed washing machines, or if he covered Dublin. 

They just wanted to find his number and ask him when he could come round.

So his conversion rate also went up.

Which meant we could afford to pay more per click.

And get into top ad position.

Which brought in even more visitors.

The happy ending to the story is that my friend ended up getting a new van and building a workshop in his back garden to fix all the washing machines.
I‚Äôd never heard his dad speak, but he quietly bought me a drink at a family gathering.
To me, the biggest benefit of Google Ads is not that you can buy "traffic", but that you can find out what people are searching for, so that you can sell it to them.

Google Ads is the purest form of cold ‚Äútraffic‚Äù.

There is an intent behind every search.

If you‚Äôre not using it to buy real time market intelligence, then you‚Äôre just buying traffic.

You can quickly test whether ‚Äúcheap‚Äù, ‚Äúreliable‚Äù, or ‚Äúqualified‚Äù works better in an ad when someone is looking for an electrician.

You can add the winner into the copy on your landing page.
The biggest benefit of Google Ads is that it can help you to build products your market actually wants, rather than what you think it wants.

You're in business to:

1) Find out what people want to buy.

2) Find out how to sell it to them.

3) Find out if you can make a profit doing so.

4) Fail fast, refine until you‚Äôre profitable, or scale up.
If someone searches for ‚Äúwedding rings Dublin‚Äù, then you know they are in the market for wedding rings, and that they are at the end of the buying cycle (since they are searching by location).

You could run a test using different ad headlines such ‚ÄúLuxury Wedding Rings‚Äù, ‚ÄúAffordable Wedding Rings‚Äù or ‚ÄúCustom Wedding Rings‚Äù.

The ad that gets the most clicks would tell you what is foremost in the mind of the searcher.

While fine-tuning this campaign you find out search volumes, cost-per-click, cost-per-lead, cost-per-sale, and whether you can get a positive ROI.

With this information you can either refine until you‚Äôre profitable or ‚Äúfail fast‚Äù and move on.
With paid search, by the time you‚Äôve got to step 4, you‚Äôve already done steps 1 to 3 and have either a profitable sales funnel or not.

The biggest benefit of Google Ads paid search is to use this purest form of cold ‚Äútraffic‚Äù to evolve your business offering so that you give the market what it actually wants, and not what you hope it wants.

Some people are on Google looking to buy and other people are looking for information.  

But how do you differentiate between the BUYERS and INFO-SEEKERS on Google?

I like to visualise

- BUYERS searching with their credit card in hand (or a phone if they're trying to ring a business).

- INFO-SEEKERS searching with a cup of coffee in hand.

For example:

Someone searching for "tumeric" doesn't know wtf tumeric is.  

They heard it might be good for pain relief and hit Google with a cup of coffee in hand.

They read something, then go back to Google with a more educated search.

"tumeric pain relief"

"tumeric with black pepper"

"tumeric side effects"

These are search terms of someone going back and forth between Google and websites educating themselves - while their coffee grows cold beside them.

"tumeric capsules"

"tumeric tablets"

"buy tumeric online"

These indicate the searcher has their credit card out (or is at least shopping around).

I think it's best to start by trying to sell to the people ALREADY looking to buy.

They're better than low hanging fruit.  They're apples already falling out of the tree, so just put your basket under the tree and let them fall into it.

If you can't sell to BUYERS then how will you sell to INFO-SEEKERS who's wallets are firmly in their pockets?

So the next time you're looking at search terms, ask yourself:

"Does that searcher have a cup of coffee in hand, or a credit card?"
We only really learn Google Ads when we have some skin in the game, but we don't want to lose our shirt in the process.

When we start a new Google Ads campaign we typically bid low and "count impressions".

This helps identify where we can get initial visitors from at lower CPCs.

We only pay for clicks.  

If no-one's searching then our ads get no impressions, we get no clicks, and we therefore have no spend.  

*** It fails safe ***

If people start clicking our ads , then we may learn for our given bid price:

- What our CPCs are.

- What our ad position is.

- What our impression share is.  

This is valuable data we don't get from the Google Keyword Planner.

You might want to sell blue widgets but find no-one's looking for them. 

You might find most people are looking for red widgets but that's super competitive.  

Selling green widgets might be your sweet spot.

Data at this stage can give businesses real time market intelligence - for a whiff of spend!

(We can learn a LOT on a $5/day or $10/day budget!)

Each time a leak is plugged, the tap is ratcheted open at the top of the funnel by increasing bids a bit more.

(All the while trying to run at whatever target profit margin the business has.)

Maybe you focus your starting budget on green widgets.

We gradually raise bids until we're getting more visitors trickling through the funnel.

We start to learn conversion rates, and try to plug major leaks.
If we can double conversion rates, we‚Äôve instantly doubled sales (which is great), AND we‚Äôve also halved our cost-per-acquisition (CPA).

Our profit margin is now too big (yep, I‚Äôve been roasted for that as well), so we can double cost-per-click (CPC) to get back to the previous CPA.

Which will often quadruple volumes.

In case you didn‚Äôt spot that let me say it another way: 

Doubling conversion rates can often multiply sales volumes by a factor of 8.

People think they need to lose a boat-load of money on Google Ads before they can get profitable.

I contend there's ways to be streetsmart about it, and that the biggest benefit of Google Ads is it helps us find out what people want to buy - and how to sell it to them.

Thanks for reading!

1. Table of contents. Here's what I follow:
1.1. Summary (if the presentation is long)
1.2. The problem: Show some early numbers for people to grasp how big of a problem you solve, from the start
1.3. Your solution: A smooth transition between both is needed

1.9. Milestones: What have you done to date? What's next? Short-term and long-term goals.
1.10. Team: Who are the founders? The other members of the team? Do you have advisors? 
1.11. Finance: What growth do you plan? The income statement goes here.
1.12 The ask (if raising)

1.7. Acquisition: Who are your customers? How do you acquire them? At what cost? And how fast can you grow?
1.8. Business Model: How do you make money? How much do you need to be profitable? If you're innovative there, show it.

1.4. Competition: Depending on how much time you have to present it, you can go for a single table
1.5. Unique selling proposition: How you're different from your competitors, and how you protect it
1.6. The market: How big is it? Did you talk to customers? What did they say?

2. Ok, now you have the structure. Next question! What tool do I use to create my deck? 
I'm a macOS user, so I'm using Keynote, animations and font choices are great. Powerpoint is doing equally well there. I'm a bit less of a fan of Google Slides, but that's up to you.

4. Do you need to buy a template? Well, a few months ago, I would have said no, but it took me sooo long to reach something decent, that I ended up buying one for 50$, and it changed everything. I'm using this one: basetemplates.com/pitch-deck-tem‚Ä¶
3. What font to use? I like Avenir Next very much, and in general, like fonts where there's a strong difference between light and bold words. You can easily highlight content. https://t.co/vllm7IfE3C

5. Never underestimate the power of visual slides. Here's an example of what our slides look like. Logos instead of bullet points, content is in separated boxes. The lower band shows your audience where they stand. By far not perfect, but giving you an idea. https://t.co/l7umGy8cLH

6. Animations. That's a personal take but I feel like slides look better with some animations, especially to show transitions between parts or concepts you pitch. Here, I show that blind people use sounds to find obstacles, and then show a map where some obstacles are silent https://t.co/A2glVEWMNl

7. Prepare several versions of your deck. That's annoying, but it will save you some time in the future. Think about how to make it stick into 5 minutes, 10 minutes of 15mn. That's the most usual format. Also prepare a version that only describes your product for domain experts. https://t.co/XnY3herk7x

11. Have backup slides. You'll never be able to stick everything in a limited amount of slides. In the version you send, remove backup slides. Have them ready for the day you present your slides. For example, more details on your competitors

10. Need to share your slides? Especially on Keynote, the export can be incredibly large. Replace videos with youtube links (paste the link on a page, it will appear as a full video in your slide). And then, move it to a PDF compressor to reduce the size: pdfcompressor.com

9. How many slides should you target? It all depends on how much content there is on it. >40 is way too much, try to remain below. I have slides with little content on each page, so I always tend to have 15 slides for a 5mn pitch for example. But you can go for less.

That's it! Hope you liked these pieces of advice. None of them is a strict rule to follow of course, but that's what we're using and has worked so far! What are your tips? #thread #startup #slides #pitch #deck
And of course, this is the pitch deck we're making with @BVollmer5 and @fasttosmile for @soundmapio

Make time for ‚Äúnormal‚Äù

After spending so much time on work together, carving out solo time is important for sure. But establishing regular routines together is invaluable. Making coffee, exercising, driving your kid to school, cooking meals‚Ä¶

Find what grounds you as a family.

Recognize work-life separation is a myth

Work stress *will* bleed into your private life. At the dinner table, during your commute, and when you least expect it. Instead of suppressing it, take it head on.

It‚Äôs OK to press pause on a convo‚Äîas long as you pick it up later.

If you liked these tweets, follow us at @chriscantino + @jaimeschmidt, and check out Jaime‚Äôs book Supermaker that goes deep into all the ups and downs of bootstrapping the business together! supermaker.com/book

Have an exit plan

Pressure‚Äôs on when your income depends on the success of the business. And few startups last forever. Take regular inventory of where you‚Äôre both at in life, and whether running a business is still serving you.

Happiness is more important than startup success.

Just listen

Late nights, no sleep. Firing that day one employee. Worried you won‚Äôt close that deal. Some problems can‚Äôt be swept under the rug, even if you‚Äôre just being paranoid. That‚Äôs when you need your partner to be there for you, to hear you.

Make room for the irrational.

Have different roles

Major disagreements come when you both feel ownership over big decisions. This is unavoidable to an extent‚Äîso be prepared. But for the day to day, explicitly define your roles, and trust your partner to do what they do best.

Support their independence.

The idea behind starting Weekend Read -

I started Weekend Reads with a simple idea to introduce some of the best thinkers and writers to the new users here on Twitter.

It's not easy to start here on Twitter without following the right individuals. This results in a lack of interest to be on Twitter. I myself have been there.

Above any profession, thinking and writing is an altogether different combination of skills that needs an insane amount of passion, practice, and patience to develop over time. 

Massive respect for them. Internet has been no less than a blessing in our life.

Not anyone can be a great writer even if they are a great thinker. 

I myself draw inspiration from all these incredible individuals here. That is what inspires me to curate Weekend Reads every week for you all.

Here is the first role. Operations Manager : twitter.com/iaboyeji/statu‚Ä¶

#1 : Keep your parent offshore in Delaware/London/Dubai/Amsterdam. Nigeria has historically treated foreign investors better than local companies. There is also some guarantee of rule of law and investor protection. Don't be a hero.
#2 : Be default remote and move often. Offices are nice but it may not be wise to have a place that can be raided by security forces looking for someone to shakedown.

#3 : Operate as a global company. Since your parent and IP are offshore, keep your banking global, intentionally hire from other nationalities and countries. Be compliant with global regulations. Have global legal and financial advisors. The cost is worth it.

#4 : Stay asset light and work with local partners. Local partners know how to navigate the local terrain you don't. Build your business model to incentivize local partners to leverage your IP and processes to make money. Don't be greedy.

#5 : Stay compliant and abreast of regulatory changes. No one can force you to have a presence in Nigeria but you need to make sure you are on the right side of Nigerian law. It may require deep changes to your operations. Work with experienced advisers to help you on this.

One of my portfolio companies has recently hit its stride, and it reminded me of how counter-cultural enterprise sales are in the current tech market. NB: by ‚Äúenterprise,‚Äù I mean high ACV, slow sales cycle, B2B-focused startups, no matter which vertical they serve.

/1

Selling to enterprises is tedious. It‚Äôs time-consuming. It‚Äôs also lucrative and sticky. The tantalizing lure of the enterprise is that once you are in, you are *in*. Do your job right, and you‚Äôll earn an annuity for decades.

/3

As B2C founders race to see who can ‚Äúearn‚Äù unicorn status fastest, B2B, specifically B2E startups, often have to hustle for half a decade before they know if they‚Äôre on the right track. All the time not confident if they‚Äôre pursuing an IPO-worthy market or a local maximum.

/2

So, if you are considering taking the leap and building an enterprise-focused startup, here are a few of the lessons I‚Äôd offer:

/4

üìà The sales uptick won‚Äôt come until year six: Can you wait that long? Unfortunately, one of the maddening aspects of building an enterprise startup is that the inflection point often doesn‚Äôt come until half a decade has passed. 

/5

It can be tough to measure progress during this time ‚Äì are you getting traction or just spinning wheels? Are you able to get enough ‚Äúwins‚Äù to keep morale, including the founder‚Äôs, high for the long-term? 

/6

üôÑ Don‚Äôt be a subject matter snob: After you‚Äôve spent the better part of a decade immersed in a market, you begin to believe that no one could possibly get up to speed quickly enough, and you start searching for domain experts. This attitude is folly from a hiring POV.

/7

Domain expertise is straightforward to teach compared to the vague and often intrinsic skills that make for a good salesperson or engineer. New hires can gain a functional level of market knowledge in 30 days of intense training; technical skills take decades to hone.

/8

ü§ù Everyone has to sell: More than 50% of enterprise success comes from distribution. Product is important, and product-led growth is a viable strategy, but everyone on the team needs to think about ‚Äúsales‚Äù as a core part of their job description.

/9

‚ÄúBuild it, and they will come‚Äù is a doomed strategy in this arena. Strategy divorced from front-line product or sales experience is useless. More than any other area of the startup ecosystem, commerce and code need to be fully integrated.

/10

By all means, get fresh thinkers on your cap table, but be sure to balance them with seasoned investors who won‚Äôt shrink when Salesforce starts competing with you, or a big deal dies on the vine after a two-year courtship.

/12

üìú Pick VCs with long track records: Newly minted VCs can be after quick mark-ups to help raise their next funds. As a result, they‚Äôve often not directly experienced the punctuated tedium that is the hallmark of enterprise sales and product development cycles.

/11

üßë‚Äçüéì Prepare to teach: Unless you are replacing an existing product in a well-understood category, you will need to educate the market. This is a slow, grinding, and often frustrating process. 

/13

Moreover, you need to educate everyone ‚Äì your team, your customers, their employees, and perhaps most importantly, the analyst who manages or will put you in a Magic Quadrant. You need the heart of a teacher and the cunning of a sales leader.

/14

üêå Move slowly and get buy-in: Enterprise sales is the art of asking for permission. So first, you need senior-level leaders to sign contracts. Then you need to get buy-in from managers. Then you need to train every line worker. 

/15

Nothing happens quickly or easily in the world of enterprise sales. Every victory is hard-won. Fortunately, the process isn‚Äôt easy on the buy-side, so your wins tend not to churn after six months. Still, strap in for a long haul.

/16

Serving enterprise customers requires a vanishingly rare combination of skills and personality traits.

Relentless execution paired with a zen-like approach to the passage of time.

Technical proficiency married with diplomatic poise.

/17

1. Orders.co - Focus on the benefits

Orders.co helps restaurants offer their food on as many online platforms as they wish from one app. 

On the landing page

They jump right into what they achieve for the customers with 4 benefit-driven subheadings. https://t.co/swD6nxcMOq

When building your landing page 

Beware of fluff.

Your competitors may build landing pages that go on and on‚Ä¶

Talking about things the readers don't care about.

Don‚Äôt do that.

- Focus on the main idea and purpose for the page.

 - Highlight the benefits.

- Talk about the features.

- Show how it works.

- Let the audience see how your service makes their day better.

Your copy doesn't have to be short. 

It just has to be as long as necessary to communicate the message to your prospect. 

Nothing more. Nothing less.

2. ClickUp - Use different types of social proof.

When you hear about social proof...

What you think of is usually ‚Äúclient testimonials‚Äù...

And how you put the images beside them to increase credibility.

But, that's not all social proof is about.

ClickUp is a free app with over 1,000 integrations for running a business

ClickUp closed $100M in funding and reached a $1B valuation in December 2020

The landing page doesn't have testimonials from business owners.

It only shows the number of reviews and number of teams on it https://t.co/8Ukc8EdoBa

Add as many forms of social proof as you have to your copy.

It doesn't have to be ‚Äúonly‚Äù human testimonials. 

Use:

- Case studies

- Trust icons

- Data/Numbers

- Social media reviews

- Testimonials

3. Code Signal - Add an FAQ section

Code Signal helps companies like Uber, Zoom, and Facebook among others to hire brilliant, qualified programmers for their business.

Just a few days ago, Code Signal secured $50M in Series C funding.

Now, let‚Äôs run to their landing page.

Code Signal‚Äôs page shows features, benefits, and testimonials.

But what ends the page is the FAQ.

An FAQ section allows you to answer all the remaining questions the readers may have about your service. https://t.co/9FjGl0iBx2

How do you know these questions before publishing the page?

By doing market research before writing.

And by answering these:

- What questions do the competitors answer?

- What areas might be unclear to the readers?

4. Virtually - Don't rely on text alone

Your landing page could contain as much text as you want

But, using only texts is not visually appealing

Virtually allows you to teach Zoom classes and get paid

Each block of text on the Virtually page is accompanied by an image.

Why? https://t.co/PaQ6VE0Gwy

Images, gifs, or videos showing your dashboard

Allow people to see what you offer and if they'll like it.

Show them mockups of every important page in your product‚Ä¶

Accompany these images with solid copy explaining the features and benefits

And let them make their decision.

5. OpenSea - Engage with the customers

Having social media presence is a big plus.

Most of us on this side of Twitter already know OpenSea (@opensea)

That's where we buy our NFTs.

Now imagine they didn't engage on social media‚Ä¶

We may not know about them today. https://t.co/z2Zy4eNfDU

Keep your landing page copy interactive...

And also use social media copy to communicate with your audience.

As people engage on social media...

More people head to your social media page...

Then to your landing page...

Before buying into your offer.

6. Yac - Embed videos on top

Yac helps businesses and teams cut time spent in meetings...

(It's anti-Zoom!!)

When you get on the website‚Ä¶

The first thing you see is a text animation‚Ä¶

Then a short video that explains the offer. https://t.co/BtbbvfjxHb

Putting videos on your landing page could drive >50% more conversions. 

All you need to do is write the copy for the video‚Ä¶

Create the video (or hire someone to)...

And embed it on top of your landing page.

Before continuing with the rest of the copy. üòÄ

7. Rightbound - Use a clear CTA

Rightbound didn't feel like the perfect example to use here‚Ä¶

But it also did.

When you first open Rightbound‚Ä¶

You notice the main CTA at the bottom of the page. https://t.co/Hf9RHiYH8r

It looks like there are no links to other pages on the landing page‚Ä¶

So you're not distracted and start clicking everything in the menu.

But Rightbound has multiple CTAs on the screen.

They're just in color white.

So you don't notice them.

(Look on top of the picture)

If you can't remove the main menu on your landing page for whatever reason‚Ä¶

Change the color to blend with the background‚Ä¶

So it doesn't distract your readers from what you want them to do‚Ä¶

‚ÄúSign up!‚Äù

Before I wrap it up‚Ä¶

A few more points for you‚Ä¶

- Focus on how you solve the audience‚Äôs problems.

- Don't be rigid. Write like a human. Keep it interesting.

- Use both features and benefits. Don't ignore one for the other.

And if you just don't know how to write...

Hire a good copywriter!

That's all for today,

I'll be sharing more copywriting tips soon.

How did he do it? Detailed observation.

He freelanced his way up the Shopify food chain and took note of every engineering request.

When the work poured in, he hired help. @DiscoLabs was born.

Gavin Ballard was done with the 60+ hour work weeks, so he left them behind to code full-time.

He founded @DiscoLabs, which eventually became a 7-figure income stream.

Disco Labs began as a digital agency but added a product development component as it grew.

Gavin had a 12-person team to begin with, and funded the operation with agency clients. 

With the agency revenues coming in, he was able to self-fund the product development projects without raising money.

‚ÄúA lot of the work we do is building a one-off solution that‚Äôs also useful to other merchants,‚Äù Gavin said.

‚ÄúWe were essentially building the same stuff over and over again but customizing it to each merchant. Once I saw the demand, a subscription product made sense for us.‚Äù

What happened next was all about spotting patterns ‚Äì listening to what customers wanted and then finding the points of overlap. 

Gavin wondered: Was there a product opportunity here?

Gavin is proud to have bootstrapped Disco Labs, but the struggle between client demands and product development forced him to rethink his priorities. 

Recently, Gavin took a cash injection of $250K from @tractorventures in a revenue-based financing deal.

Sustainable growth and the work-life balance have long been at the heart of @DiscoLabs culture.

He wouldn‚Äôt give that up for the sake of a few million in the bank -- he remains a bootstrapper at heart!

Does this mean Gavin is open to raising money again in the future?

Not if it means burdening himself or his team with a mountain of new responsibilities.

‚ÄúWith this money in the bank, we can afford to offboard some of our larger clients. Once we‚Äôve transitioned them to a new agency, we can spend all the time we‚Äôd have spent on their projects on Submarine instead, which will accelerate things for us.‚Äù

Want to read Gavin‚Äôs full story?

Read it on Bootstrappers, our publication that covers bootstrapped startups.

1. Minimize risk

Clicking a CTA often takes time (signing up) and money (paying for a good or service).

Don't give people a reason to second-guess.

Support your CTA with reinforcing value statements: https://t.co/Z68RIvKmR8

2. Click-to-result flow

Most CTAs are "sign up" or "buy now."

Instead, drive users directly into your product without friction. Get them to a profile page they can customize. Or in @microacquire's case, directly into the listings page. 

Get them in your ecosystem! https://t.co/U8fTTlPElS

3. Soft CTA

Running an email campaign? Try a soft CTA. 

Instead of a discount button or a "buy now" offer, get more people to your landing page to explore before they commit: https://t.co/hVp4u46Mvf

4. Implied scarcity

Scarcity, or FOMO, is almost always cheesy.

"Hurry, buy while supplies last!" 

People don't like being told to buy. Instead, imply scarcity:

"Reserve your spot today" implies that it might be gone tomorrow, without saying it will be. https://t.co/RX6dzgNYGT

5. Psychology of instant gratification 

Humans desire instant access, gratification, results. 

Great CTAs use this factor via words like "see it on your site" to appeal to those looking for fast solutions. https://t.co/avrkexstZX

6. Impulse buying

CTAs that appeal to impulse purchases are great for ads. 

Verb, value, urgency taps into this by offering a needed solution at the click of a button: https://t.co/p14n1BcpS8

7. Design flow

CTAs are more than just copywriting. Design can produce action too.

Elements like arrows tell visitors where to focus their attention and encourage a natural flow from headline to button click: https://t.co/su6IL017CS

8. Social proof

Social proof isn't just for quotes in the middle of your landing page. 

It should also surround your CTA, effectively telling users they won't regret signing up: https://t.co/avfxUxFuvn

9. No friction words

Friction words include: sign up, submit, invest, get started. 

These signal more steps, more time, more effort. Get users into your offer without the notion of added time and effort. https://t.co/aCXQXtcGu7

‚ú® There's always reasons to not do something if you're looking for them ‚ú® 

You will always be in the middle of a project, you'll always be waiting for the next promotion. There is never a 'right' time to leave a company where you are comfortable, so don't wait for it.

‚ú® No decision is permanent ‚ú®

Leaving a big company can feel like a huge decision, but in tech it's common to flow through all sorts of companies. Don't be scared of making a decision for fear that it is the wrong one. It is easier than you think to change your mind.

‚ú® Don't be afraid to mess up a 'good thing' ‚ú® 

If you have spent years at a company building your reputation, advancing up the ladder, and developing relationships, it can be intimidating to think about 'starting over' somewhere new.
In fact I would recommend that you specifically don't wait until you are unhappy to look for a new job. It will actually be harder to make a decision when you're clouded by urgency and burnout.

‚ú® You do not need to be unhappy to look for a change ‚ú® 

A misconception I had was that people would wait until they were unhappy to look for something new. You can be really happy and fulfilled, and still find a better opportunity for yourself somewhere else.

‚ú® Trust yourself! ‚ú® 

Finally, and it's a cliche, but: trust your instincts. Having the itch to try something new is reason enough to explore!

‚ú® No one will be mad at you for leaving ‚ú®

When leaving Facebook, I was worried that I would be upsetting my mentors and colleagues because they had invested so much time in building my skills. But this wasn't the case ‚Äî good mentors just want the best for you!
You may be concerned that you will not be able do the same thing somewhere else. It is not a coincidence that you accomplished this the first time, if you did it once, you can do it again.

The company with the best insights about its customers wins over the competition. 

However, many businesses still struggle to wrangle all their raw data into something that‚Äôs usable.

Holistics (@holistics_bi) empowers everyone to answer their own data questions without the need to rely on the data team. 

The platform lets technical teams define & curate a set of business metrics so non-technical teams can build their own reports & charts without writing SQL. https://t.co/TveKGZoElK

The value of a self-service data intelligence platform is clear from the numbers. 

Holistics has 250 customers across 30 countries who use the software to make their data accessible and actionable.

Currently, the company does $1.5 million in ARR and they are on track to hit $2 million by early next year. 

Their platform runs over 5 million queries every month to support customers‚Äô analytics operations.

91% of their customers say they can deliver business answers within a day of adopting Holistics. 

It‚Äôs also one of the top analytics tools for Software Advice FrontRunner 2018-2021 and a Capterra Top Performer for 2021.

Rather than a startup founder or CTO, Huy Nguyen (@iamhuy) sees himself as a builder. 

He‚Äôs been a software engineer since high school. He moved away from Vietnam to study Computer Science at the National University of Singapore (NUS). https://t.co/RtGMYMWX6t

There, he joined a special program for entrepreneurs, where they fly students to another country to work for a startup for a year and learn the ropes. 

He went to Sweden to work for a bio haptics startup and to Palo Alto to work as a software engineering intern at Facebook.

When he graduated from university, he joined a startup called Viki (it‚Äôs like Hulu, but for Korean dramas) as a data engineer. 

During that time, Huy was part of a small team that built the entire data infrastructure for the business, along with a lot of internal data tools.
According to Huy, ‚ÄúOne of the tools evolved into something useful. And then I thought, ‚ÄòHey, this could actually help a lot of other businesses too.‚Äô"
That tool was a dashboarding solution that allowed a user to input a query and quickly get a data report, without the need for a data engineer.

‚ÄúI asked my boss, my CEO, my CTO, and my CFO if I could run with it and they were all very supportive. I‚Äôm very grateful for that,‚Äù Huy says. 

‚ÄúThen I went out to find co-founders who would be able to turn this into a real business with me.‚Äù

In 2015, Huy and his two co-founders, Vincent Woon and Thanh Dinh, had everything they needed to start Holistics. 
In the early years, Holistics grew very slowly. 

As first-time founders, they had to go through some rough patches to get to where they are today.

He says that the mistakes weren‚Äôt necessarily about doing something wrong ‚Äì it was more about the fact that they weren‚Äôt doing certain things they should have been doing. 

According to Huy, ‚ÄúWe had these blind spots and we kept thinking ‚ÄòWhy didn‚Äôt we know about this earlier?‚Äô‚Äù

The trio of founders each had their own strengths: 

Huy was the product guy

Vincent was the sales and operations guy

Thanh was the one with engineering and infrastructure expertise. 

The only skill set that was missing between the three of them was marketing.

One of their biggest marketing challenges was Holistics‚Äô positioning. 

‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt even really know what positioning meant at the time, we weren‚Äôt sure if messaging was the same thing‚Ä¶ So, deciding how to market the platform in general was a struggle.‚Äù

Finally, they realized their customers‚Äô primary pain point: They were frustrated that, despite all the business intelligence reports that the data team prepared, other departments kept coming back to them for every small change in report structure.
With their ideal customer pinpointed, the Holistics team went back and updated all their sales, marketing, and product materials to reflect that common pain point and underlying belief.

That‚Äôs how Holistics landed on their current messaging and go-to-market strategy. And ever since, things just started to click. 

Their growth picked up, they had more happy customers, and the support team had an easier time.

Bootstrapping = not raising money.

And since you‚Äôre not, you won‚Äôt be participating in many, if any, startup events.

Why not? 

They‚Äôre all about fundraising.

And fundraising is none of your concern as a bootstrapped founder.

So what do you do instead?

‚Üì

To successfully bootstrap, you need to:

1. Focus on customers
2. Go where they are, not where others go
3. Care deeply about them
4. Help them with their problem/need/want

With this approach you‚Äôll make your customers successful.

In return they‚Äôll make you successful.

‚Üì

As a result of that, you won‚Äôt become a well known name in the startup ecosystem.

You‚Äôre chasing customers, remember?

- NOT general publicity
- NOT fame in the mainstream

You don‚Äôt need any of that.

Here‚Äôs what you need.

‚Üì

You focus on customers.

Because you‚Äôre focusing on customers, you don‚Äôt care about general publicity.

You care about niche publicity. You only need your market to know you.

And your customers likely don‚Äôt read TechCrunch, Hacker News, or go to local startup events, anyway.

‚Üì

1. Skip the SEO Line

Ranking for keywords takes time. Skip the wait by doing outreach to existing content.

Search "best [tool/service/etc]" variations.

Pitch them on why you should be added to the list.

Getting listed will drive immediate, targeted referrals to your site. https://t.co/9iKHX2UpQ4

2. Get high-traffic affiliates

‚Ä¢ Google content related to your product, like: "how to write headlines" 

‚Ä¢ Scrape first 3 pages of URLs 

‚Ä¢ Email sites giving lifetime product for free

‚Ä¢ Get them in your affiliate program

‚Ä¢ Repeat with dozens of new keywords https://t.co/7c5QJ0tDK7

3. Send cold emails

The only personalization your cold emails need is a relevant offer. 

"I loved your podcast" is cheesy. Skip it.

Make a list of 1,000 that could benefit from your product.

Send them a simple email to see if they are interested. Most won't be, but some will: https://t.co/mzUKesU1rw

4. Give your product to niche influencers

Then get out of their way. Don't force them to share your product. 

Give them free access and free rein. They might just share it with thousands of people for free. https://t.co/4BeYmcflqQ

5. Sponsor newsletters

Search for an engaged niche newsletter that aligns with your target market. 

Sponsor it with a content-forward native advertising approach rather than a noisy and invasive sales offer: https://t.co/UlzuUL3pGB

7. Start writing content now

SEO takes time. The sooner you start writing valuable content that answers search queries the better. 

Write one article per week that targets a specific keyword.

6. Give value in niche Slack groups

Search for: "[niche] slack groups"

Join groups where potential customers are. Engage with a focus on providing valuable tips, content, and stories.

8. Optimize your landing page

The easiest way to get more sales is converting more of the traffic you already get, not getting more traffic.

Copywriting and design can dramatically improve conversion rates. 

I created a guided playbook on this: copycourse.io

Appeal to FOMO and exclusivity.

The learning from the story below is that just innovating is not enough. You can fail or succeed in #innovation, but you won‚Äôt succeed in innovation if you are not solving the problem.
2/17

In 2002, @Microsoft unveiled its Tablet PC. Gates believed in tablet computing and said: ‚ÄúWithin five years, I predict it will be the most popular form of PC sold in America.‚Äù However, the Tablet PC ran Windows - the same Windows designed for laptops and desktops.
3/17

Gates was not solving a problem people really had, he was creating a product without deeply understanding customer‚Äôs pain. He just created a mini-PC and was betting that people need to do same jobs on Tablet PC than on desktop.
4/17

Even the name ‚ÄúTablet PC‚Äù gave away its genetic defect: it wasn‚Äôt defining any new category by solving existing customer pains which other categories didn‚Äôt.
5/17

Instead it was trying to be a PC in a slightly different form factor‚Äîa form factor that wasn‚Äôt really suited for the kinds of things people usually did with PCs.
6/17

Computerworld magazine wrote: ‚ÄúRather than envision what people would really want to do with a tablet and then design for that, @Microsoft instead force-fit Windows onto it. Windows XP was a great desktop operating system, but it was bloated overkill for a tablet.‚Äù 
7/17

Within five years, instead of flying off Best Buy shelves as Gates foretold, the Tablet PC was a goner. It failed to create or spark a new category.
8/17

Eight years after Gates‚Äôs announcement, @Apple CEO Steve Jobs took the stage for one of his famously dramatic product unveilings. The room went dark, and Jobs put up a picture of an iPhone and a MacBook laptop, with a question mark in between. 
9/17

‚ÄúIs there room for a third category of device in the middle?‚Äù - Jobs said to the audience. He dismissed past efforts to fill that spot, saying they were just bad laptops.
10/17

But, he said, there had to be a place in our lives for a device that is ‚Äúso much more intimate than a laptop and so much more capable than a smartphone.‚Äù

With that, he showed the first iPad.
11/17

And then Jobs uttered the magic words‚Äîthe words that showed @Apple had thought about this new product in a new way.
12/17

The ‚ÄúiPad creates and defines an entirely new category of devices that will connect users with their apps and content in a much more intimate, intuitive and fun way than ever before.‚Äù
13/17

The iPad wasn‚Äôt a laptop or a phone. It solved a new problem particular to the mobile-social-cloud era:

üëâPeople needed a device that they could carry around and use to watch videos, shop, read magazines, or muck around on Facebooküëà
14/17

It didn‚Äôt have to have the power and bulk of a laptop, but it did need a bigger screen than a smartphone. Jobs had identified a new problem, and developed a new kind of product to solve it.
15/17

As he announced the iPad, Jobs made us see that we had this problem and that @Apple had the very best solution ever.
16/17
