I set up quarterly check-ins with competitor CEO‚Äôs. And I openly shared data.

You have to give to get. So give your information and ask for advice.

My intent with these calls was to get acquired, not be the buyer.

That‚Äôs where the story gets interesting.

At 4x our size our own growth wouldn‚Äôt be enough to make the combination compelling. And they would be in control.

The next step is where a great board can be the difference maker.

‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt we just buy them?‚Äù asked a board member.

I built a good relationship with the CEO of the target company. And he expressed interest in acquiring us. 

My plan was working!

But, we were growing 100%+ and they were barely growing.

That‚Äôs a problem.

So I asked the other CEO what he thought.

He hemmed, he hawed, he asked me how I would pay for this. But he was open. Their sluggish growth was bothering him also.

We negotiated very high level deal terms and I asked him for 30 days to get it funded. He agreed.

Too big, no money, blah blah was my answer.

‚ÄúWe treat it like it‚Äôs ours now. We built the deck, create the model and start pitching.‚Äù 

This made sense to me.

We needed to an interested and slightly crazy investor however. 

But first we needed the target company to agree.

So I made some calls.

First call, bingo! Sent the deck, the model, the negotiated terms (no formal term sheet existed yet).

Within a day we were on calls with the target CEO working on the term sheet.

This was actually happening. Now it gets real.

This insane plan may actually work. But now we need a big check and the clock is running.

I also had been doing quarterly calls with reputable VC‚Äôs in our space.

Having these relationships was critical. They knew me, knew the business and were tracking us.

Full transparency was the only was to achieve this. We built the integration plan together.

So, after a lot of turbulence we got the deal done within 60 days.

It was rough. 

We went from $2m > $10m ARR overnight. 15 people turned into 80.  And I was running the place.

They were my tribe and we were about to step up.

So we meet every week as a company and I provided full transparency.

This was a crazy plan and they needed to know it. We needed to do our day jobs but prepare for something much bigger.

Term sheet got executed and into DD we go.

Now we have a big VC to lead the deal and drive the diligence.

I still had to get my board aligned but that proved easy. This was there idea!

And I needed to get my small 15 person company aligned.

- We had an incredible board who thought strategically. Building the right board was important to me when we began and it paid.

- We had built relationships before we needed them. We freely shared our data with competitive CEO‚Äôs and VC‚Äôs.

Culturally the businesses were very different and this would become a major problem (for another thread).

We were the dog who caught the car, holding onto the bumper for deal life.

We were able to stretch and make this happen for a few reasons:
- We got the right partner who could provide time leverage. Getting money proved easy. But we needed experience in bringing a complex deal together.

When the time came to make it happen, we could leverage these relationships. You have to give to get.

- We provided full transparency inside the company to get everyone‚Äôs help. We were small. Hiding the reality would help no one. And it‚Äôs a whole lot more fun.

It turns out, Dre was doing a tour in Asia for his Up In Smoke Tour, and needed someone awesome to go with them vlogging the behind the scenes shenanigans with him, Eminem, Snopp Dogg, etc.

It was obviously an absolute dream come true.

Following an incredible rise in Hip Hop & Youtube so much so that he starred in one of THE most iconic youtube ads ever, Jamal was very much a rising star.

This radar did not escape the man with arguably the single greatest eye for talent in global hip hop history...

Dr Dre.

He told me this story in both embarrassment but willing to share with humility how someone who'd made a career out of doing this one thing (videos) had buggered up the single biggest opportunity he'd had to date, and what he could learn from it.

He had been taken on tour personally by Dre and had nothing to show for it.

Needless to say, he recalled the most awkward conversation of his life - which didn't go down too well! as you might imagine!

His lesson?

Always bring/record back ups.

Seems obvious now indeed!

Somehow (and he wasn't that clear with me HOW this happened in it's entirety) he filmed the whole tour, had the best time hanging out with all his heroes but then....

All the footage got damaged/deleted/broken.

He literally lost all of it - and had NOTHING to prove it.

Most people would hide that story, he was willing to share it.

Good leaders make mistakes.

Great leaders share them with the world so they can learn too.

RIP to a pioneer.

If you can learn one thing from him - it's to stay humble and exercise humility in pursuit of learning!

In the early days of a product, don‚Äôt focus on making it robust.

Build Minumum Viable Product (MVP) fast, it‚Äôs all you need to test if there is a good market for your startup. You can even use No-code tools if you don‚Äôt have engineering team at the beginning.

Market matters more than anything else. You can develop the best product in the world, but if the product isn‚Äôt meeting a significant, must-have user need, it‚Äôs a pointless endeavor. Focus on the problem you‚Äôre solving, onboard users with that problem early.

The approach should always be problem first and then how tech can be used to solve the problem not the other way round. Whether it is blockchain, AI, or web3 doesn‚Äôt really matter except the solution is solving a significant problem customers have.

Product market fit happens when the customers are buying the product just as fast as you can make it. Money from customers is piling up in your company account. You‚Äôre hiring sales and customer support staffs as fast as you can.

1. Build in public

Share your progress, not your goals

Sharing allows people to praise you not on your results, but on your process.

Learn in public. Build-in public.

i.e: @theandyhsu amazon intern, learning in public, sharing lessons on tech design!

2. Public Portfolio

Think of your Twitter as a public portfolio.

Showcase work, learnings, expertise, etc.

Establish yourself as an expert in your field & people will listen.

i.e: 
@dklineii : teaching leaders to build great teams
@Ridderingand: deep dives on product design

4. Your bio is your resume 

Include credibility and social proof. 

- Where have you worked?
- What do you know?
- What are you tweeting about?

This gives people the opportunity to get a quick glance at your profile 

Then, decide if they're interested.

3. Post consistent content 

Your content needs to be centered around ONE niche. 

Based on your interests, what you're most knowledgable on, etc. 

Not sure what niche to focus on? Check this out: 
twitter.com/brendangahan/s‚Ä¶

5. Power of DMs

Don't sleep on the magic of DMs.

Career moves and long-lasting connections occur through DMs.

Spark a conversation, offer your help on something, you never know what will happen next.

@Aaditsh's guide on DMs:
twitter.com/aaditsh/status‚Ä¶

6. Provide Value

Engage with others in a similar niche to you.

Comment and share other posts.

Showcase that you're engaging to engage, not just to gain something in return. 

One insightful comment is worth more than thousands of one-word responses.

8. Join a Community 

This will definitely speed up your progress.

I was recently a part of Makers Mark created by @brandonthezhang & @aaditsh.

10/10 recommend.

Learned about audience building + met some really cool people in different spaces. 
twitter.com/brandonthezhan‚Ä¶

7. Find your community 

Every niche likely has an established community. 

Like: Marketing Twitter, web3 Twitter, etc.

Find your people - interact and make connections.

Working together is the way to go.

9. Followers aren't everything 

Don't focus on getting thousands of followers. 

I had less than 1,000 followers when building my connections. 

Just be consistent, build relationships, and you'll see the results pouring in.

To recap:

1. Build in Public

2. Public Portfolio 

3. Consistent Content

4. Bio is your Resume

5. Power of DM's

6. Provide Value

7. Find your community

8. Join a community

9. Followers aren't everything

@darjagutnick [Not a founder but!] my 'cure' for taming the need to always be productive is to make a to-do list for days off that includes things like: sleep-in, take a stroll by the river, read for a few hours, journal outdoors, call your mum etc.

@darjagutnick Realizing that success is at least 90% outside of your control puts that extra 0.00001% effort in perspective. Also, your team needs you rested and inspired, not harried and hyperfocused on minutia

@darjagutnick My tip consists of this line of thinking: I can never do in a day what I would like to see done in a day. There is always more to do that what can be done. So many things have to wait until you get to them, I am sure they can wait a couple days more.

@darjagutnick Realizing it‚Äôs a marathon not a sprint helped me. Just imagine you would be a professional soccer player. As such you would never train 24/7 because it would be harmful to you and your team. Your muscles need time to rest and repair. The same is true for founders.

@darjagutnick Another angle to look at it: the best marathon runners sleep for 12h per day. Sleep does not only help for physical recovery but also for mental recovery. They could run more every day but it‚Äôs a marathon, not a sprint :)

@darjagutnick Totally feel you. You need to sharpen the knife. High performers in every industry understand that & take time off to do exactly that. Nothing bad about it. Best way for me to do that is to leave behind all things that could distract me from that or chose an activity...

@darjagutnick ...that doesn‚Äôt allow for distraction by work-related stuff - e.g. you cannot take a call or read emails when driving a motorbike üèç  or when you are in the middle of a fight (martial arts) - just as an example...
@darjagutnick This one is hard, I started forcing myself to go places without cell signal and force a digital detox

@darjagutnick You owe it to company to take some days off (not just 1). Your task is to lead&delegate, not lots of grunt tasks, and you can only what‚Äôs important after unwinding and taking a step back.

You‚Äôre only human, like everyone, and govt forces days off on everyone else for reasons.

with the core rules needed to be complied with before floating a business, because they believe we are in Nigeria where laws are not really being enforced (let just assume without conceding that it is so that laws are not really being enforced in Nigeria). This is a fundamental..

error and it goes to the root of the business. In fact, it is a self-deceit which may ultimately lead to self-defeat. It is a mistake that will definitely tell on the business as time goes on. For instance, many business entities have folded up today due to non-compliance...

with relevant rules. Another factor to consider is the high possibility of unconsciously making bad deals as a result of lack of access to legal advice. Also, not complying with the relevant rules will definitely limit the scale and growth of business. No government body or...

serious corporate organization would deal with a business entity which does not comply with relevant basic rules.

Thus, as a business owner who has complied with relevant rules, one will have the courage to take his business to any level and thereby expand its operations...

This overrides any immediate gains that non-compliance with rules may seem to offer.

On a related note, some startups do erroneously believe that business regulatory compliance starts and ends with the Corporate Affairs Commission (CAC). However, there is more to business...

regulatory compliance than CAC, which may just be the starting point. 

As a business owner, you may also need to get necessary approvals from or registrations with relevant regulatory authorities like Federal Inland Revenue Service (FIRS), Council for the Regulation of...

Engineering in Nigeria (COREN), National Agency for Food and Drug Administration and Control (NAFDAC), Architects Registration Council of Nigeria (ARCON) etc. 

In conclusion, our position is that in order to be regarded as a serious player in the business world, you need to...

do your due diligence to determine the relevant rules needed to be complied with and ensure compliance with same. You are at liberty to engage a lawyer to cover this ground for you, while you focus on business.

@daliakatan Prioritisation & Deadlines are key. Tempting to do 1837922836383 things at once. But that might not be productive or fruitful.
Also, PM has to play bad cop and put their foot down. Might get some nasty glares due to this üòõ

@daliakatan Don't focus on making profit since DAY 1. It's important to improve product and gain users and customer traction as well. Your margins can be very thin, and it's okay. You're a startup, you have expenses. Invest in MARKETING but consider it to return in long term, be creative.

@daliakatan A few things come to mind: talking to your users as much as possible and sharing those insights with the team, being super focused on what you work on/prioritize, and lastly, giving your team room to focus on what they do best and removing blockers for them
Quick thank you to those chiming in - I‚Äôm listening and taking notes! ‚úèÔ∏è

@daliakatan a few things on my list ‚úçÔ∏è

1. define your success metrics / north star and give team the opportunity to figure out how to achieve it 

2. understanding not all feedback is good feedback that should be actioned upon  

3. quantify the possible impact of changes before you execute

@daliakatan Just because you can build it doesn't mean you should. 

Especially in the early days, there has to be a ton of focus on delivery of the core value. Save the animations and "delight" factors until after you've nailed the core experience. (This is nuanced, but generally speaking)

@lolitataub Align with their budget. Focus on that. Avoid unsolicited proposals by all means. They open your tech to competitors.

@lolitataub Register on SAM.gov and look at SBIR. Some SBIRs like AFWERX and the DOD ones are specifically meant as a pipeline for small startups to develop a technology for use by government customers so it‚Äôs solid to use for non-dilutive seed funding as well
@lolitataub Get money as soon as you can from them, ideally b4 shipping anything and prepare for a slow,multi stake holder sales cycle. Not my favourite customer segment to work with.

@lolitataub I saw selling, government, and I immediately thought of the govt contracting boss @Christine_CLT. Maybe @Amplify_CLT has tips for you on this.

@lolitataub Depends on the domain but I've seen companies bring in funding via SBIR loans, PACTA matching grants at later phases and Agency/Branch specific development project dollars, all prior to commercial contracts.

@lolitataub There are people far more experienced than me on this, but knowing the procurement process for the specific agency you're trying to sell to inside out and backwards is the starting point. Knowing key decision makers, finding internal champion, & filling out paperwork are also key
@lolitataub Know where you land in their procurement structure. Above the quote or bid limit? Process/requirements to become a vendor?

@lolitataub If local or muni, all about direct relationships w/ decision makers. If state, all about proximate political/social networks and checking the right procurement boxes, if federal‚Ä¶being a subcontractor is best way to get paid faster and deal with less procurement pain.
@lolitataub Don't quit your day job selling to the government. You'll run out of $ first.

@lolitataub Would be helpful to know what they‚Äôre selling (and if it‚Äôs unique) to what level of government at what price point in which country. 

(Even if you can‚Äôt say all of that here, the advice will be flimsy if at least some of these aren‚Äôt known‚Ä¶)

@lolitataub Make sure all the policies and procedures required for govt. contracting is done. Be prepared to keep track of every penny and focus on compliance. If you are pre-rev/startup, see if you can subcontract with a contractor to get into their process.
@lolitataub Happy to help/advise the startup, if needed. Been doing govt. contracting for 18 years. DM is always open.

@lolitataub I've done several RFPs with both state & federal bodies. It's crazy but a lot of times, the govt ends up signing a small niche company to partner with vs a big name. Worth trying the RFP route to get your foot in. Happy to discuss more.

@lolitataub For munis, sell to individual depts/ agencies, pilot for 60 days, and price below the procurement threshold. Avoid RFPs and speak to dept directors directly. Direct email outreach is most effective sales tactic.
@lolitataub Is there a very, very good reason that a prospect with an extremely long sale cycle who is a very very slow pay is an ideal sales target for a bootstrapped company with no revenue?

@AngeZanetti Start solo, work with people until you find someone you really click with.

@AngeZanetti I was lucky. My four co-founders are friends & ex-co-workers from GE Financial, Microsoft & PayPal, with the exception of one.

They all have the separate capabilities needed to meet our strategic objectives, share the vision & our average known duration is 14.5 years.

@AngeZanetti Finding a cofounder is a bit like dating. You don't marry someone after knowing them for 5 minutes (usually üò¨). Same with co-founding. Start simple. Build in co-founder ramp ups after a trial period. Chemistry is almost as important as raw skills (in very early stage anyways)
@AngeZanetti The key is value alignment and complimentary skill sets. Also someone who is persistent as hell and willing to pivot when necessary
@AngeZanetti You date before you get married: do some small project or mvp together first. Also: clearly state what you expect of your partner, put it in writing.

@AngeZanetti If you are choosing technical co-founder - hire him for a couple of weeks on money basis. If no finances you can try to negotiate him to build you some prototype part-time. Self confident tech guy that is really interested in your idea will for sure agree
@AngeZanetti You can try us. Let‚Äôs chat ?
@AngeZanetti I don't know if there is a "guide". I think it's a match between feeling and skills
@AngeZanetti Trust plus mutually beneficial incentives and aligned personal growth visions.
@AngeZanetti What easier finding a co founder or finding a wife LOL
@AngeZanetti Product, marketing, sales, operations. Which are you strongest at? Pick someone with main strengths in one of the other areas and experienced in rapid growth.

@AngeZanetti What has worked for me for 10 years:

- same values and principles (e.g. honesty)

- complemented skills (not overlapped, easier for accountability)

- we don't sweat the small things (like one getting a bit more than the other in certain situations)

@AngeZanetti As a technical founder, my trick is not to üò¨

@AngeZanetti The key is to pick someone who has done this before - built a business and understands resilience, persistence, patience and has strength of character to see things through.  Not someone flaky who just wants to be a founder in name only and who just wants to 'give it a shot'.

@lolitataub Same question to large corporations

@lolitataub i think no direct answer. Depends on sector/country/industry. But most startups as they mature the founders have limited visibility in day-to-day ops. Hiring good people helps as founders will end up delegating.  What stage this startup is at the moment?
@lolitataub Look at what we‚Äôve done at Buildium. Value the reduction of churn as a starting point.
@lolitataub As a solo founder, I relate to this question. It was the primary reason I‚Äôve limited access to my product. I, and I alone, was ‚Äúcustomer service.‚Äù
@lolitataub I've worked with @hire_horatio before and they do an amazing job with outsourced CS teams.

@lolitataub Lots of hacks here. A great CRM (avoid Salesforce like the plague), brilliantly-written templates, dispersed mystery shopping (everyone does it), CX-smart OKRs (often geared to raising or maintaining NPS), everyone reads a fair bit of Tony Tsieh.

@lolitataub Depends a lot on industry and company type but a good rule of thumb is automate and establish self serve as much as possible.

We reduced number of support tickets to a mobile network provider by establishing their CRM, konwledge base, chat flows, FAQ‚Äôs etc
@lolitataub Don‚Äôt forget to get a good trainer.

@lolitataub Start really small and have deep conversations with a few dedicated customers. Curate from the answers the fans give. Then scale that with automation as much as possible.
Go back to superfans, ask them to test new customer service flows, and get feedback. Build more automation.
@lolitataub B2b? B2c?

@lolitataub Maximize all the features of tools like @Intercom and @Twilio for customer comms, and never leave a customer hanging. #1 focus should be quick response times to customer inquiries with meaningful, templated replies that eliminate unnecessary follow-ups.
@lolitataub Hire retired / senior citizens to do front line customer support (eg actually answer phones)
@lolitataub Amazing triaging powered by increasing automation is the key to success here, I believe.
@lolitataub @onboardio can def help. They are amazing!

@lolitataub Lead by example. If it‚Äôs truly important to you as the founder you‚Äôll spend time in it, provide support, and will bring the right leaders to maintain the quality you want. 

The everything store has great examples of Bezo‚Äôs obsession for this.

@lolitataub Game changer when we were starting: Get a good CRM and really take advantage of the features (we use hubspot)

And several of our clients use services like ours (remote admin, virtual assistants) to help them scale.

@lolitataub Know your core metric.  For example, resolutions within X hrs. Never, ever let this slip.  Make it clear that when there's a tradeoff between efficiency and the core metric, the core metric wins.  Every single time.

Then identify and remove bottlenecks to improvement 1 by 1.

@lolitataub Hire someone early that can learn the ins and out of your product or service and the relationship you want to have with your customers so they can train new hires as you grow with a sense of foundation and why things are done the way they are.
@lolitataub Make it a core value and the answers come; there is no consistent growth without consistency in deliverables quality, of which effective customer service is a basic element.
@lolitataub What‚Äôs your industry?

@lolitataub One of the things is definitely to focus on onboarding and setting up a code of conduct.

How do you want your customer success agents to speak with someone, how should they be dressed, how do they end a conversation, how do they document valuable insights.

@MacConwell Totally. Plus if an investor wanted to dig deeper on something, they‚Äôd just ask follow ups, so no need to drone on.

@MacConwell Yes yes yes, I can attest to this. The meetings I loved most were the 10-15 minute pitches followed by solid questions and conversation afterwards. The concise but effective pitch allowed us to dive really deep which was an extremely good use of time

@MacConwell It‚Äôs important to remember that you aren‚Äôt going to close anyone in 30 minutes. In 10 minutes I should know if I would want to spend another 10 hours getting to know you and your team, or business, if there is a business, or team (when we both have more time).

@MacConwell It's also important that the founder take a few minutes to ask at least three questions: 

Who in their space they have invested in or spoken with and passed on and why, 
On average how much they invest and at what stage, and 
What stage the fund is at.
@MacConwell Great advice. Good sign of a 30 min pitch meeting last an hour from questions?

@MacConwell I once ran into an investor I liked at the entrance of the restroom of a hotel. I stopped him in his walking tracks, introduced myself, my company and what we've done in less than 120s. He was impressed and instantly handed me over to his investment officer. The rest is history.

@MacConwell If both the entrepreneur and the investor did their home work the first 30min meeting would be focusing on "fit" and not on menial things that can be found on a web site or in a presentation.

Startup tip 101:
